content.description: Fun Route, watch out for the ledges!
Very easy route, good for beginners.
content.location: Found in the Bouldering area. Far right side of wall, next to fallen tree.

content.description: 3 bolts, start on crack/flake at the left side of the slab.  Follow bolts.
content.protection: 3 bolts with 2 bolt anchor... or pads

content.description: Slab on easy edges between bolted routes.
content.protection: 2 bolt anchor to TR off of, or pads.

content.description: Start by sucker punch and traverse left until the ledge, once your standing on the ledge your done
Wet corner with what must be an appropriate name.

One of the longest routes at the quarry. Starts in a left-facing dihedral on the broken corner to the left and down the wall from quagmire. If this location description is confusing, then just look for the only route with 4 bolts up it (although the 4th bolt is useless, and probably for the 5.13 on the face just to the right of this climb). The crux of the route is about 5-feet off the ground, where some stemming will make up for less-than-ideal hands. Past the crux is easier ground to the top.
content.protection: 3-4 bolts with a 2-bolt anchor at the top. Bring a cordolette or two 48" slings for the TR set-up. The first bolt is rusted and folded in half, its unusable.

content.description: Starts two hand on the chalky side pull. Bump your left hand up to the small crack/crimp just above the start hold. Dino to the sloper about 4 feet (rough estimate)above and to the right of the start hold and then top out of the route! Solid route for anyone who likes pumpy slab routes![[]]
content.location: Start by leaving the parking lot. Take a left on to the trailhead diagonal from the climbing and picnic area. Follow the trail until you see a sign for a bouldering area.

content.description: A very fun line! Climb up to the slab to the right of the obvious horizontal crack. There is no protection until you reach the crack. Traverse the crack with solid hands and poor feet until the crack diminishes. From there, follow up the right facing dihedral to the top. Use the tree as an anchor to belay up a second.
content.protection: A couple of hand sized cams in the horizontal.
content.location: Start just to the left of The Beginner's Crack and finish near the top out of Black Ice.

content.description:
Bolted route just to the left of Quagmire. Up a zig-zagging thin crack with positive, but thin, side-pulls. Continuously 5.10 to the top without any terrific rests. 

  I personally enjoyed this route quite a bit. Worth doing a few laps on for a workout.
content.protection: 3 bolts. No bolt anchor for TR, so bring long webbing for trees or the small (but adequate) boulder some 15-20 feet back from the edge.

content.description: Featured sort-of arete.  Nice climb with offset balance moves.  Doesn't get enough attention, in my opinion.  5.6 is listed in the park handout, but seems sandbagged to me.
content.protection: Use trees or boulders for TR.  Long anchor material needed.
content.location: Between the blank 5.13 wall and the Quagmire dihedral.

content.description: 3 Bolt slab route.  Flat landing so bouldering it is  all good if you are OK with a little highball action.
content.location: Farthest route on the right of the climbing area.

content.description: The arete and flake to the left of 6-foot flake.
Steep wall that looks to seep water a bit...  Looks like good crimps to some big reaches at top.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor set back from the edge quite a bit.
content.location: On the steep wall to the right of the obvious wet corner.  See photo.

content.description: Easy crack climb.. as long as your here you might as well wander up it.
content.protection: 2 hand sized pieces to lead.. or a pad if you are smart. You can set up a TR with a few cams and such.
content.location: Around the arete to the left of Six Foot Flake.  Obvious big crack.

content.description:
Quarry Park & Nature Preserve is an old quarry in Stearns County near St. Cloud.  It contains about 17 "routes" that are between 20-30 feet tall.  It is a Stearns County Park and has its own guidelines for climbing which can be found on their website at co.stearns.mn.us/1450.htm#Rock

  Registration is required to climb and there is a fee to use the park.  Quarry park also has some swimming holes which are fun when the weather gets too hot to climb.
